ownership-mindset-story.text: The Mindset Shift. Junior mindset: I write code for tickets assigned to me. Senior mindset: I'm responsible for this feature succeeding, from idea to production. That's the ownership difference.
Clarifying Requirements. Owners don't just accept vague specs. They ask questions, push back on unclear requirements, and define exactly what 'done' looks like before writing a single line of code.
Designing the Solution. Write the design doc. Draw the diagrams. Plan for edge cases. Get buy-in from stakeholders before you start coding. This saves massive time and rework later.
Implementing with Excellence. Write the code, tests, and documentation. Use AI to accelerate. But remember: owners self-review before asking others. Quality is your responsibility.
Ship and Monitor. Get through code review. Deploy to production. Watch the metrics. Fix issues that arise. Ownership doesn't end at merge—it ends when the feature is working for users.

ownership-lifecycle-story.text: The Complete Journey. Owning a feature means owning every phase of its lifecycle. From the first requirements conversation to the post-deployment retrospective, you're the one driving it forward.
Requirements Phase. Meet with stakeholders—PMs, designers, other engineers. Write a requirements doc with clear success criteria. This is your north star for everything that follows.
Design Phase. Create your design document with architecture diagrams, data flows, and API contracts. List every edge case you can think of. Get this approved before you code.
Implementation Phase. Now you code. Use AI to accelerate. Write tests as you go, not after. Keep commits atomic and well-described. Update your design doc when you discover new edge cases.
Review and Polish. Address code review feedback promptly. Do manual testing—don't trust only unit tests. Update documentation. Prepare your deployment checklist and rollback strategy.

Deploy and Retrospective. Deploy to production. Monitor the initial metrics. Then write your retrospective: what went well, what you'd do differently, what you learned. Share those learnings with your team!

real-feature-story.text: Not a Toy Project. This capstone isn't a toy project—it's a real feature that provides real value. Something at work, an open-source contribution, or a tool your team will actually use.
It Must Be Real. An actual feature at work. A meaningful open-source contribution. A tool your team will use. Something with real impact, not just practice.
Multiple Components. Not a one-file change. It should touch frontend and backend, or multiple services, or involve database changes. Real features have complexity.
Has Stakeholders. Someone must care about the outcome. A PM, a designer, users, or at least other engineers who'll use what you build. Accountability drives quality.
Deployable to Production. It should reach production—or be blocked only by business reasons, not technical completeness. When you're done, it should be ready to ship.
